BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 27, 1918.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

LACROSSERS HOLD ANNUAL PARTY 0. D. K. HOLDS FINAL MEETING

FACULTY MAKE SUMMER PLANS

1921 SUFFERS DOUBLE DEFEAT

C. Herbert Baxley Elected Captain for
Next Year— Father Bill Schmeisser,
Reaney Wolfe and Dr. Abercrombie Among Speakers.

Bev. Smith Elected Vice-President and
A. B. Coleman Secretary-Treasurer.
Football Practice and Honor System Among Things Discussed.

A Large Number to Give Courses in
Summer School—Several in Service
and Many Will Work for
the Government.

Sophomores Defeat Freshmen in Close
Baseball Contest by Score of 6 to 5
and Run Away With Lacrosse
Game Last Saturday.

The annual lacrosse party and
meeting was given the team by
Captain Schmidt last Wednesday
evening at the Hopkins Club.
After a five or six course dinner
and speeches by all members of
the team and the invited guests,
the election of captain for next
year's team was held. C. Herbert
Baxley, '19, star inhome of the
team this spring, was elected.
This is Baxley's third year on the
lacrosse squad, he having won his
H. A. A. in lacrosse during his
freshman year.
The party as a whole was a
great success; the dinner went all
the way from soup to coffee—a
necessity for all lacrosse banquets
in order to keep the men awake
during Bill Schmeisser's speech,
according to Reaney Wolfe—and
the speeches were excellent. Captain Schmidt presided, of course,
and called on Dr. Abercrombie,
former captain and member of five
Hopkins lacrosse teams, for the
first speech. Dr. Abercrombie
spoke of the great fight all the
Varsity teams have made this year
under the Most trying conditions,
complimented the team on bringing back the championship to Hopkins, and told them that all Hopkins men were proud of them.
The next speech was from
"Fritz" Sadtler, who told some of
the experiences of a freshman on
the team, his remarks being supplemented by Joe Brennan, the
other fresh H man. The other
members of the team and the manager were then called on in their
turn, and told of their adventures
in New York during the recent
Crescent trip, or started the ball
rolling to beat Lehigh next year
"on their own back-lot." The hit of
the evening was undoubtedly Tiff
Williams, who proved himself a
true comedian in giving an account of his experiences with
"Rube" Jarrett at Coney Island
and in the "Big City." Graduate
Manager Corner announced that
the sweaters had been ordered and
would arrive at an early date, and
congratulated the team on its
coaches and the wonderful work
they have done for the team.
Captain Schmidt then gave a
splendid tribute to Alex Wolfe,
captain of the team this year
until he enlisted in the Aviation
service. He told of the letters he
had received from Alex during the

The Omicron Delta Kappa held
its final meeting of the year last
Tuesday evening at the Johns
Hopkins Club. The members of
the faculty present were Dean
Brush, Dr. French, and Major
Guild.
The only elections that took
place were those for the offices of
Vice-President and SecretaryTreasurer. Beverly Smith, Jr.,
who will be a Senior next year,
will hold the former office, and
Aylett B. Coleman, Jr., the latter
An important topic of discussion was the question of conflict
between drill and football practice next year. A plan was suggested in which drills would be
held every day from 12:30 to 1:30,
lunch would be eaten until 2:00,
and laboratories would be open
from 2:00 until 5.00.
In connection with the honor
system, it was proposed that all
communication in examination
rooms be included with the
things prohibited in the pledge.
The matter of interesting men
of the Maryland high schools in
coming to Hopkins was brought
up. Although no speakers have
been sent to the prep schools so
far, it is very probable that Dean
Brush and Major Guild will make
a few tours before the end of the
term.
Major Guild outlined a plan,
which, if followed sometimes,
would undoubtedly arouse much
outside interest in the Battalion
and likewise in the University.
It was that of organizing the Battalion as a mounted signal corps
unit. This could probably not be
done, however, until after the war.

Judging from reports, the Faculty will accomplish much during the summer vacation in their
untiring efforts to serve our country in their best capacity. The
following faculty members have
definitely decided upon their summer work:
Several members of the faculty
will complete some of the tasks
that they have put off until summer. Dean Murray P. Brush will
spend the vacation at Rome, N.
Y.; Dr. John C. French at Blue
Ridge Summitt, Pa.; and Dr.
Herbert E. Greene at Cape Cod,
Mass.
Dr. Herbert S. Jennings will do
research work at the University.
Dr. Duncan S. Johnson will,
study the problem of diseases of
wheat. He will make his investigations in Alabama, and in the
States north of it.
Dr. Caswell Grave will be in
service in the Ordnance Department, in New Jersey.
Dr. Jacob Hollander will spend
the summer in Baltimore.
Dr. C. K. Swartz will be engaged this summer in government
geological research in Maryland.
Dr. Greenbaum has volunteered
to make official' translations for
the Government. He will continue his own research work until called into service.
Dr. Robinson will spend the
summer making literary productions and doing archeological investigation. He will spend part
of the summer in New England.
Dr. C. L. Powell will probably
spend the summer working in the
Red Cross.
Dr. Greene will spend most of
the summer at his home at Cape
Cod.
Dr. William Kurrelmeyer will
do farming on the campus.
Dr. Ethan A. Andrews will
spend most of his time in the
biological laboratory.
A large number of instructors
will teach in ,the summer school,
which, opens here July the ninth
and closes August the sixteenth.
Dr. Edward F. Buchner is the
Director of the Summer Courses.
Dr. J. Elliott Gilpin, John H.
Latane, Arthur C. Millspaugh,
Robert B. Roulston, Henry Slonimsky, Robert A. Stewart, Mr. C.
Griffin and Mr. John E. Uhler
are among the members of the
Faculty„who will be occupied with
teaching the summer courses.

Taking advantage of a slump
in Welliver's delivery, the Sophs
gathered 4 runs in the fourth session, and 2 more in the fifth; at
the same time they held the Freshmen to 5 tallies. In the second
round Webb smashed out a fly to
center which went past Bratt's
head with such a breeze that it
blew him over; while Webb, in
the meantime, circled the sacks
for a homer. Winn, the '20
pitcher, in avoiding being caught
off second in the fifth, spiked
himself, breaking his ankle. Litman finished for him, and pitched
some - nifty ball. The umpires
gave some raw decisions, calling
Greenbaum safe at home in the
fourth when he was a yard off,
making Fries safe at first in the
eighth instead of being out by
three feet, and putting Lederer
out at third in the ninth.
The lacrosse game was more or
less a scramble. The Freshmen
were able to land 2 only in the
first half and none in the second.
The Sophs rounded in about 12
towards the end, their entire defense, including Dougherty, left
their positions and tried shooting
goals, while Ferdy Meyer, the
"field judge," curled up in the net
and 'went to sleep.
The scores:

Hullabaloo Not Ready Till June 15.

Owing to the shortage of labor,
the "Hullabaloo" will not be issued to the subscribers until June
the fifteenth. Subscriptions will
be received at the Hopkins Postoffice until May the thirteenth.
Although at first it was decided
not to publish a "Hullabaloo" this
year because of the present state
of affairs, the editors felt it their
duty to leave some record of the
various activities that have taken
place in the course of the year.
The main feature of the "Hullabaloo" is its extreme simplicity.
It is in keeping with the time in
that it is an economical issue,
The class histories will be concise,
but clear.

Freshman Orators Hold Forth.

The class of '21 held on Monday evening, the 20th, at the Hotel
Altamont, a social affair that had
been for some weeks previous a
subject of great speculation among
their rivals, the Sophs. Untimely
interference was effectually prevented by keeping the place a
dark secret, from all but the committee, until an hour before it
started. When the meeting was
called to order, it was found that
over fifty were present, including
the guest of honor.
As in all the gatherings of the
great, the first thing done was
the taking of the flash-light photograph, copies of which will be
soon on sale. (This should be in
great demand, as a prominent
feature is the handsome figure of
the guest of honor). A rush was
then made for the Hooverized refreshments. The crowd next sat
down in a large circle and "lit
up." Addresses were made by the
guest of honor, President Carey,
Vice-President Marcuse, Secretary
Heiner, Treasurer Pegram, the
chairman of the Pin Committee
and the captains and managers of
the class athletic teams. Aesthetic
dancing and stories of Frederick
were some of the further sources
of enjoyment. The evening wound
up with the singing of various
college and other songs by the entire chorus, and a snake dance by
the same. [Notice: Those who
took more than one pack of cigarettes are requested by the committee to kindly return the same,
or their equivalent, as the treasurer is hard up.]
LACROSSERS HOLD ANNUAL PAPTT

(Continuedfrom page 1)
year, and of some of the things
he has done for Hopkins Lacrosse.
Reaney Wolfe spoke next, and
made one of the best speeches of
the evening. He complimented
everyone on the showing made
this year, but warned them
against getting a swelled head,
and urged them all to come out
and work again from the beginning next year, and make it even
better. He complimented especially those men who were shifted
from defense to new positions on
the attack early in the season, and
those men who sat on the bench
as reserves during a great part of
the games. There are no first and
second string men on the Hopkins
lacrosse team, he said, but just
a great combination, all working
together for the success of the
team.
Father Bill Schmeisser made
the final speech, and it was a new
one. He let the team on to some
of the coaching secrets he and
Reaney have used during this and
former years. He spoke of the
great work the team has done this
year, and of the greater things he
hopes of them next year, if they
all come out and work with the
same spirit.

When the Reserve Officers'
Training Camp at Plattsburg
opens on June 3, there will be
seventy-four Hopkins men in attendance. In view of Major
Guild's request that the Hopkins
quota be increased, the authorities have allowed us 74, instead of
the original quota of only 43. Although no comment is forthcoming
from Battalion Headquarters, it
is believed that the increase in
quota is to a great degree ascribable to the excellent showing of
the Hopkins Corps at the inspection.
Arrangements have been made
for a special car, leaving Union
Station on Sunday, June 2, at
noon. Nearly all the Plattsburgers will go up on this train, arriving at camp in a body. They
will report in the uniform of their
respective grades.
At Plattsburg, the future officers will be given a thorough infantry training. Since this camp
has been used before for the same
purposes, the equipment and the
conditions of the camp will be
the best. The training will be
over on July 3—just a month
after it began. The men are not
only looking forward to an enjoyable time, but they expect to
profit greatly by the expert training they will receive.

BALTIMORE, MD

MAY 27, 1918

More Intramural Athletics.

In this time of efficiency and
preparation for service to the
country more should be done for
the physical benefit of the Hopkins students body as a whole.
The administration has urged
that college athletics and especially intramural contests be carried on; hence, we • believe that
next year an extensive system of

WEBB LEADS TEAM IN BATTING AVERAGES FOR 1918
Bloomsburg and Littman Are Runners-up-Benson and Moriarty Star Fielders.
Welliver Carries Off Pitching Honors---Purcell and Sickel Field Well.
Many of Team Available for Next Year-Prospects Good.

The batting race for the season of 1918 was the closest in many
years. Capt. "Dick" Benson started off like a house afire gathering
five hits in the first two games, but then took a slump and failed to
connect safely with the ball for the remainder of the season. Webb,
with his consistent hitting, had things all his own way until Jack
Jones broke into the game in place of Rogers. His first time at bat
the little third-sacker smashed out a homer to left. He continued
clouting the pill, until, in the Catholic University game, he tied
Webb with a double. However, he lost his eye in the Army battle,
and, owing to his small number of trips to the plate, his percentage
dropped. Bloomsburg started off poorly, but proved to be a real dark
horse, being Webb's sole competitor at the finish. Had the season
continued much longer it is a question as to who would have emerged
on top. Larry Littman also starred with the stick.
Webb, besides carrying off the batting average, leads in the runscoring and extra-base hitting. Benson and Jones tied for stolen
bases.
In fielding Benson is in a class by himself. During the entire
season behind the bat, he made 54 putouts and 17 assists without a
single miscue. Moriarty was also in the 1.000 class, catching six hard
flies. Purcell managed himself well in the field, chalking up to his
credit 84 putouts and letting four slip by. him, while Sickel tied him
with 17 putouts, 4 assists and 1 error.
Welliver carried off the pitching honors, working exceptionally
well in every contest but the Holy Cross game, which was his debut
on the mound.
It is interesting to note that nearly the entire team will return
next year, and it is expected that they will acquit themselves well
next season.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 27, 1918.

AN IMPRESSION OF THE FRONT
By Dr. HARRY FIELDING REID:

4

A year ago, in. May, 1917, the
Foreign Service Committee of the
National Research Council, found
itself at Chalons on the Marne,
on a visit to the French front.
The weather was beautiful, the
flowering shrubs and trees were in
full bloom. The guns in actioh
a few miles to the north were not
audible, and to the casual view
the place seemed very much like
a French garrison town in time of
peace. In the afternoon of the
day of our arrival, we went by
automobiles to see the front lines.
As we drove along the fine French
roads, through a fairly level country, we passed many lories moving
forward or to the rear; here and
there we saw a camp of horses, or
a park of supply wagons; occasionally a group of soldiers would
saunter by, usually carrying picks
or spades, rifles being conspicuously absent. Now and then an
automobile carrying officers, or a
man on motorcycle, would dash
by at a break-neck pace; but the
country seemed peaceful.
The first indication of our approach to the front lines, was
sight of a row of captive observation balloons; they were placed
about three miles behind the front
and three or four miles apart;
and thus, from a distance, marked
the position of the lines. Sometimes six or eight were visible at
once. As we approached, the distant booming of cannon could be
heard; but this section was inactive at the time of our visit, and
the firing was not rapid. We left
the automobiles and went to an
observation post, which was placed
at the edge of a wood, so concealed by blanches as to be invisible at a small distance. From
this point we could look over the
lines a short mile ahead. It was
an interesting and surprising
sight: a broad, very gently rolling
country, with patches of wood
here and there, with the grass gone
from the part near the trenches,
which, in this region, were not
'very easily distinguished. Behind
us was the row of French captive
balloons, and at a greater distance
in front the enemy balloons; here
and there overhead an aeroplane
floated in the sky, the noise of its
engine distinctly audible; frequently we would hear the sound
of a bursting shell and see the

Extracts From "Hank" Chalmer's Letters.
"Hank" is now with the Y. M. C. A.
serving at the front. He will ever be
remembered as a Hopkins all-around
man, and for his genial disposition.
The following are extracts from his
letters:

"If things work out as I expect,
I shall be assigned to a dugout
on tire French front working with
the French soldiers. There has
been a call for volunteers for these
posts, because they can't send a
man there against his will; so, I
volunteered, and they think I shall
be accepted. If I get the job it
will put me on the fighting line
with the most marvelous opportunity for service I have had.
The French people are wonderful,
and I hope I may be able to help
them in their courageous fight.
They say that we can render no
more important service than our
work among the French."
"I am now only about twenty
miles from the front, and there is
so much snow that it is impossible
to proceed at once to my Foyer.
It is hard to get to, anyway, and,
especially so, with two feet of
snow on the ground. I shall stay
where I am today and go on again
tomorrow. Last night I slept in
a room having one pane of glass,
the other openings were covered
with thin gauze. The mirror in
the room had a hole in the side
and there was a hole in the wall.
The shutters and ceiling were
scarred with holes. All this
wreckage was done by bombs."
*
*
"I am in the midst of things. I
got up at five o'clock to take a
train for my post. It was pitch
dark and there were no lights.
All the cars in the little narrowguage railway were filled, but the
conductor gave Bill and myself
a place in an empty mail car. It
was cold and we had to keep moving to keep warm * * * * We
had to stop at headquarters for
a safe-conduct pass and missed the,
train, so at nine o'clock tonight
I shall take the train to the last
train stop, arriving about eleven
o'clock and must walk the rest of
the way, about six kilometers.
* * * Arrived at eleven
o'clock, and the men found a place
for Bill and me to sleep in a barn.
We slept on the floor without
blankets. It was cold, but endurable. * * * * I arrived all
right where I now am, and

"I was awakened about three
o'clock last night with the sound
of firing. The Foyer was shaking, and I could see the flash of
the guns lighting up the sky.
They were going so fast that I
could hardly distinguish separate
shots and the noise was deafening. It lasted about an hour and
then quieted down. They expect
two or three bombardments. * *
* * The French clearly have the
upper hand. Defensively they cannot be beaten, and it is only a
matter of time before Germany
is licked. The troops are splendid
and are wonderful fighters."
"Yesterday was the first open
day for my Foyer. The building
was full of soldiers most of the
day. They are tremendously appreciative of the Foyer."
"Yesterday there was a presentation of the legion of honor to a
captain, and the military medal
to a corporal of the Zouaves. First
they had a Review, a salute to the
colors, then presentation, and another Review and salute. The
Review passed right by where I
stood, and every officer saluted
me. When the colors passed, I,
of course, stood at attention and
saluted, and the color bearer, who
is a lieutenant, dipped the regimental colors of one of the finest
fighting units in the world in
recognition. Of course they did
all this to me because I am an
American."
"I said I was going to mention
barrages and the like only as I
would mention rain, but as I have
mentioned rain once, I'll take another shot at the guns. It is especially interesting tonight because they are going on the complete swing of three quarters of a
circle. I can hear the guns in
all four directions, front, back
and both sides. One quarter,
however, is open. The way the
guns go, though, you feel as if
you were completely surrounded.
The 'noble six hundred' haven't
anything on me. I can add one
direction to their three."

Lauds Freshman Spirit.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER: t

Sir—As the college year is
drawing to a close, I take this opportunity to say a few words
about niy class and to the University.
I have heard some fellows complaining of the lack of spirit in
the Freshman class. It seems to
me that when we got organized,
after the first few weeks, we have
had a splendid spirit. Certainly
the various athletic teams cannot
kick about the Freshmen not being well represented on them. To
the football squad, we gave Carey
and Jones, and many others,
whose spirit was none the less
good, even if their opportunities
were less great. Baseball stars
from the class of '21 were Weillye; Webb and J. Jones. Track
had Mulliken and Van Ness. On
the lacrosse team were Brennan
and Sadtler. Besides the men
named, there were many others
who came out and gave of their
best, that Hopkins might be successful in the field of sports. Our
class, as well as the University,
is deeply grateful to them.
In other things, too, the Freshmen have maintained a fine spirit.
The few,regulations set down for
them, during the first term were
very well adhered to. Altogether,
the class promises to be Ole to
maintain, with honor to itself, the
traditions of the University.
I look back •upon the college
year, now ending, as one of the
happiest of my life, and as I look
forward to next year, I feel considerably saddened, when I think
of the s changes that will have
taken place, of the students who
will not return, and, perhaps, I
myself will not be here. If this
last should be the case, I want to
thank the professors for their fairness to me in my studies, and to
ask the students to join me in a
good, old Hullabaloo for Hopkins.
FRESHMAN.
Concerning the Employment Bureau.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—We have at the University
here, although many students may
not know it, an Employment Bu-

The Physics II Lab.
(An Extract from the Will of those
students finishing Physics II.)
* * * And the little Place
Up under the Roof of the M. E. Building
We leave to the class that takes Physics II
Next Year.
You will go in, in the afternoon (perhaps),
Find out from the Instructor what its
all about,
And get some Data.
If you think there is too much work
attached
Accidentally smash a vital part of the
apparatus
Before too many readings are made.
You will pursue the elusive Milligram
With the Meter Stick.
You will read to a tenth of a division,
And repeat it, getting a reading ten
divisions out.
When the seconds-clock stops at a crucial point
You will have to tickle it with a hatchet.
You will crack ice like Bartenders,
And concoct strange mixtures
Of mercury, sodium, sulphate, camphor
And universal, wax.
You will take as your watchword
The term "Arbitration";
That is, if readings do not agree,
Reconcile them.
After a time you will become so good
That you will be able to report on experiments
Without performing them.
This will be lucky, as just before
Tne end of the term
You will' be informed that you cannot
Take the examination until you report
On about a dozen experiments
That you will have never thought of
doing.

smoke and earth thrown up where
it had struck; once a fire burst
out where a dump of fusees had
been struck; but there was a general suggestion of peacefulness
over the country, and, strain our
eyes as we might, not a soldier
was visible; we looked through
the powerful glasses at the observation post—not a man to be
seen; the place seemed deserted.
But well we knew that thousands
of men were in the trenches or in
the dugouts within a short distance of us, paying the price of
eternal vigilance that liberty
might be saved. Death, from an
invisible source, hovered about;
and the officers warned us that
if we exposed ourselves to view
a German shell was likely soon to
land among us. This lesson was
taught us in a very decisive way
a few days later at Fort Douaumont near Verdun. After seeing
the various underground passages,
• we had gone on top to look about.
As near Chalons the country
looked peaceful and deserted. A
French 75, so camouflaged that it
was hardly visible at a distance
of 50 yards, barked sharply from
time to time, as tho' to indicate
that the fortress was not open to
strangers. We stayed but a few
minutes, and had scarcely gotten
under shelter, when, with a loud
explosion, a German 77 landed
where we had been sitting, followed ten or fifteen seconds later
by a second. It was probably
sport to the German gunners, but
they didn't see us again.
It was absorbing to watch the
reconnoitering aeroplanes. They
swept majestically through the
air like great soaring buzzards.
As we looked, a black splotch
would suddenly appear in the air
in the neighborhood of a plane;
then another, and another, until
eight or ten could be seem. They
marked the bursting of the antiaircraft shells. Gradually they
dissolved and disappeared, and the
aeroplane sailed on undisturbed,
seemingly contemptuous of the efforts to bring it down.
As a
fact, very few are destroyed in
this way.
The battle field about Douaumont was one vast collection of
shell holes; from a distance the
hill looks as though it had been
trampled over by great herds; but
a nearer view shows that the soil
has all been overturned and the
formerly smooth surface is now
merely a collection of intersecting
shell holes. Not a foot of the
original surface remains. The
French alone fired 360,000 shells
in one day when they retook the
fortress. It was gruesome sight;
cartridges, broken guns,fragments
of shells old accoutrements, lay
scattered
'about. Some shell holes
contained rain water stained a
deep red. An arm, a foot, or
larger parts of bodies could be

seen in places projecting from the
sides of the holes; and there was
a stench that pervaded the whole
place. There must be thousands
of bodies covered up in the ground
on this hill. In the immediate
neighborhood of Fort Douaumont,
though they had been clearing up
for several months, remains were
still being uncovered. We found
the same general conditions at
Vimy Ridge; the ground was so
torn by shells, that the former
German trenches were scarcely
recognizable.
In our drives across the country, we passed many villages in
utter ruin. Some had been destroyed in the natural course of
battles, others in sheer wantonness. The Kaiser is lately reported to have congratulated the
people of Aix-la-Chapelle that
their country had not suffered the
fate of northern France. But
what can be said of a government
that, for its own advantage, is
willing to inflict such disaster on
a neighbor and be complaisant because they have been spared? We
want no German peace. It is to
be hoped that the Allies may obtain so complete. a victory that
they will be able to hold the German government strictly responsible for all it has done. In the
words of Premier Lloyd George,
"Swash-buckling through the
streets of Europe must be treated
as a crime."

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 27, 1918.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

LACROSSERS HOLD ANNUAL PARTY 0. D. K. HOLDS FINAL MEETING

FACULTY MAKE SUMMER PLANS

1921 SUFFERS DOUBLE DEFEAT

C. Herbert Baxley Elected Captain for
Next Year— Father Bill Schmeisser,
Reaney Wolfe and Dr. Abercrombie Among Speakers.

Bev. Smith Elected Vice-President and
A. B. Coleman Secretary-Treasurer.
Football Practice and Honor System Among Things Discussed.

A Large Number to Give Courses in
Summer School—Several in Service
and Many Will Work for
the Government.

Sophomores Defeat Freshmen in Close
Baseball Contest by Score of 6 to 5
and Run Away With Lacrosse
Game Last Saturday.

The annual lacrosse party and
meeting was given the team by
Captain Schmidt last Wednesday
evening at the Hopkins Club.
After a five or six course dinner
and speeches by all members of
the team and the invited guests,
the election of captain for next
year's team was held. C. Herbert
Baxley, '19, star inhome of the
team this spring, was elected.
This is Baxley's third year on the
lacrosse squad, he having won his
H. A. A. in lacrosse during his
freshman year.
The party as a whole was a
great success; the dinner went all
the way from soup to coffee—a
necessity for all lacrosse banquets
in order to keep the men awake
during Bill Schmeisser's speech,
according to Reaney Wolfe—and
the speeches were excellent. Captain Schmidt presided, of course,
and called on Dr. Abercrombie,
former captain and member of five
Hopkins lacrosse teams, for the
first speech. Dr. Abercrombie
spoke of the great fight all the
Varsity teams have made this year
under the Most trying conditions,
complimented the team on bringing back the championship to Hopkins, and told them that all Hopkins men were proud of them.
The next speech was from
"Fritz" Sadtler, who told some of
the experiences of a freshman on
the team, his remarks being supplemented by Joe Brennan, the
other fresh H man. The other
members of the team and the manager were then called on in their
turn, and told of their adventures
in New York during the recent
Crescent trip, or started the ball
rolling to beat Lehigh next year
"on their own back-lot." The hit of
the evening was undoubtedly Tiff
Williams, who proved himself a
true comedian in giving an account of his experiences with
"Rube" Jarrett at Coney Island
and in the "Big City." Graduate
Manager Corner announced that
the sweaters had been ordered and
would arrive at an early date, and
congratulated the team on its
coaches and the wonderful work
they have done for the team.
Captain Schmidt then gave a
splendid tribute to Alex Wolfe,
captain of the team this year
until he enlisted in the Aviation
service. He told of the letters he
had received from Alex during the

The Omicron Delta Kappa held
its final meeting of the year last
Tuesday evening at the Johns
Hopkins Club. The members of
the faculty present were Dean
Brush, Dr. French, and Major
Guild.
The only elections that took
place were those for the offices of
Vice-President and SecretaryTreasurer. Beverly Smith, Jr.,
who will be a Senior next year,
will hold the former office, and
Aylett B. Coleman, Jr., the latter
An important topic of discussion was the question of conflict
between drill and football practice next year. A plan was suggested in which drills would be
held every day from 12:30 to 1:30,
lunch would be eaten until 2:00,
and laboratories would be open
from 2:00 until 5.00.
In connection with the honor
system, it was proposed that all
communication in examination
rooms be included with the
things prohibited in the pledge.
The matter of interesting men
of the Maryland high schools in
coming to Hopkins was brought
up. Although no speakers have
been sent to the prep schools so
far, it is very probable that Dean
Brush and Major Guild will make
a few tours before the end of the
term.
Major Guild outlined a plan,
which, if followed sometimes,
would undoubtedly arouse much
outside interest in the Battalion
and likewise in the University.
It was that of organizing the Battalion as a mounted signal corps
unit. This could probably not be
done, however, until after the war.

Judging from reports, the Faculty will accomplish much during the summer vacation in their
untiring efforts to serve our country in their best capacity. The
following faculty members have
definitely decided upon their summer work:
Several members of the faculty
will complete some of the tasks
that they have put off until summer. Dean Murray P. Brush will
spend the vacation at Rome, N.
Y.; Dr. John C. French at Blue
Ridge Summitt, Pa.; and Dr.
Herbert E. Greene at Cape Cod,
Mass.
Dr. Herbert S. Jennings will do
research work at the University.
Dr. Duncan S. Johnson will,
study the problem of diseases of
wheat. He will make his investigations in Alabama, and in the
States north of it.
Dr. Caswell Grave will be in
service in the Ordnance Department, in New Jersey.
Dr. Jacob Hollander will spend
the summer in Baltimore.
Dr. C. K. Swartz will be engaged this summer in government
geological research in Maryland.
Dr. Greenbaum has volunteered
to make official' translations for
the Government. He will continue his own research work until called into service.
Dr. Robinson will spend the
summer making literary productions and doing archeological investigation. He will spend part
of the summer in New England.
Dr. C. L. Powell will probably
spend the summer working in the
Red Cross.
Dr. Greene will spend most of
the summer at his home at Cape
Cod.
Dr. William Kurrelmeyer will
do farming on the campus.
Dr. Ethan A. Andrews will
spend most of his time in the
biological laboratory.
A large number of instructors
will teach in ,the summer school,
which, opens here July the ninth
and closes August the sixteenth.
Dr. Edward F. Buchner is the
Director of the Summer Courses.
Dr. J. Elliott Gilpin, John H.
Latane, Arthur C. Millspaugh,
Robert B. Roulston, Henry Slonimsky, Robert A. Stewart, Mr. C.
Griffin and Mr. John E. Uhler
are among the members of the
Faculty„who will be occupied with
teaching the summer courses.

Taking advantage of a slump
in Welliver's delivery, the Sophs
gathered 4 runs in the fourth session, and 2 more in the fifth; at
the same time they held the Freshmen to 5 tallies. In the second
round Webb smashed out a fly to
center which went past Bratt's
head with such a breeze that it
blew him over; while Webb, in
the meantime, circled the sacks
for a homer. Winn, the '20
pitcher, in avoiding being caught
off second in the fifth, spiked
himself, breaking his ankle. Litman finished for him, and pitched
some - nifty ball. The umpires
gave some raw decisions, calling
Greenbaum safe at home in the
fourth when he was a yard off,
making Fries safe at first in the
eighth instead of being out by
three feet, and putting Lederer
out at third in the ninth.
The lacrosse game was more or
less a scramble. The Freshmen
were able to land 2 only in the
first half and none in the second.
The Sophs rounded in about 12
towards the end, their entire defense, including Dougherty, left
their positions and tried shooting
goals, while Ferdy Meyer, the
"field judge," curled up in the net
and 'went to sleep.

Hullabaloo Not Ready Till June 15.

Owing to the shortage of labor,
the "Hullabaloo" will not be issued to the subscribers until June
the fifteenth. Subscriptions will
be received at the Hopkins Postoffice until May the thirteenth.
Although at first it was decided
not to publish a "Hullabaloo" this
year because of the present state
of affairs, the editors felt it their
duty to leave some record of the
various activities that have taken
place in the course of the year.
The main feature of the "Hullabaloo" is its extreme simplicity.
It is in keeping with the time in
that it is an economical issue,
The class histories will be concise,
but clear.

Freshman Orators Hold Forth.

The class of '21 held on Monday evening, the 20th, at the Hotel
Altamont, a social affair that had
been for some weeks previous a
subject of great speculation among
their rivals, the Sophs. Untimely
interference was effectually prevented by keeping the place a
dark secret, from all but the committee, until an hour before it
started. When the meeting was
called to order, it was found that
over fifty were present, including
the guest of honor.
As in all the gatherings of the
great, the first thing done was
the taking of the flash-light photograph, copies of which will be
soon on sale. (This should be in
great demand, as a prominent
feature is the handsome figure of
the guest of honor). A rush was
then made for the Hooverized refreshments. The crowd next sat
down in a large circle and "lit
up." Addresses were made by the
guest of honor, President Carey,
Vice-President Marcuse, Secretary
Heiner, Treasurer Pegram, the
chairman of the Pin Committee
and the captains and managers of
the class athletic teams. Aesthetic
dancing and stories of Frederick
were some of the further sources
of enjoyment. The evening wound
up with the singing of various
college and other songs by the entire chorus, and a snake dance by
the same. [Notice: Those who
took more than one pack of cigarettes are requested by the committee to kindly return the same,
or their equivalent, as the treasurer is hard up.]

When the Reserve Officers'
Training Camp at Plattsburg
opens on June 3, there will be
seventy-four Hopkins men in attendance. In view of Major
Guild's request that the Hopkins
quota be increased, the authorities have allowed us 74, instead of
the original quota of only 43. Although no comment is forthcoming
from Battalion Headquarters, it
is believed that the increase in
quota is to a great degree ascribable to the excellent showing of
the Hopkins Corps at the inspection.
Arrangements have been made
for a special car, leaving Union
Station on Sunday, June 2, at
noon. Nearly all the Plattsburgers will go up on this train, arriving at camp in a body. They
will report in the uniform of their
respective grades.
At Plattsburg, the future officers will be given a thorough infantry training. Since this camp
has been used before for the same
purposes, the equipment and the
conditions of the camp will be
the best. The training will be
over on July 3—just a month
after it began. The men are not
only looking forward to an enjoyable time, but they expect to
profit greatly by the expert training they will receive.

MAY 27, 1918

More Intramural Athletics.

In this time of efficiency and
preparation for service to the
country more should be done for
the physical benefit of the Hopkins students body as a whole.
The administration has urged
that college athletics and especially intramural contests be carried on; hence, we • believe that
next year an extensive system of
'inter-class athletics would not
,only prove invaluable to the men,
but would also meet with their
hearty approval and cooperation.
Last year a basketball league
of the four classes was organized
with great success. Witness this
spring the interest evinced in the
track, baseball, and lacrosse contests between the two lower
classes. There is no reason whatever in this time of physical efficiency why interclass games in all
the main branches of sport should
not meet with the most encouraging results. When this system finally became firmly established, the scarcity in members
of the upper classes would be to a
large extent offset by their superior experience. However, if
for any reason the interclass system presented disadvantages, bat-

WEBB LEADS TEAM IN BATTING AVERAGES FOR 1918
Bloomsburg and Littman Are Runners-up-Benson and Moriarty Star Fielders.
Welliver Carries Off Pitching Honors---Purcell and Sickel Field Well.
Many of Team Available for Next Year-Prospects Good.

The batting race for the season of 1918 was the closest in many
years. Capt. "Dick" Benson started off like a house afire gathering
five hits in the first two games, but then took a slump and failed to
connect safely with the ball for the remainder of the season. Webb,
with his consistent hitting, had things all his own way until Jack
Jones broke into the game in place of Rogers. His first time at bat
the little third-sacker smashed out a homer to left. He continued
clouting the pill, until, in the Catholic University game, he tied
Webb with a double. However, he lost his eye in the Army battle,
and, owing to his small number of trips to the plate, his percentage
dropped. Bloomsburg started off poorly, but proved to be a real dark
horse, being Webb's sole competitor at the finish. Had the season
continued much longer it is a question as to who would have emerged
on top. Larry Littman also starred with the stick.
Webb, besides carrying off the batting average, leads in the runscoring and extra-base hitting. Benson and Jones tied for stolen
bases.
In fielding Benson is in a class by himself. During the entire
season behind the bat, he made 54 putouts and 17 assists without a
single miscue. Moriarty was also in the 1.000 class, catching six hard
flies. Purcell managed himself well in the field, chalking up to his
credit 84 putouts and letting four slip by. him, while Sickel tied him
with 17 putouts, 4 assists and 1 error.
Welliver carried off the pitching honors, working exceptionally
well in every contest but the Holy Cross game, which was his debut
on the mound.
It is interesting to note that nearly the entire team will return
next year, and it is expected that they will acquit themselves well
next season.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 27, 1918.

AN IMPRESSION OF THE FRONT
By Dr. HARRY FIELDING REID:

4

A year ago, in. May, 1917, the
Foreign Service Committee of the
National Research Council, found
itself at Chalons on the Marne,
on a visit to the French front.
The weather was beautiful, the
flowering shrubs and trees were in
full bloom. The guns in actioh
a few miles to the north were not
audible, and to the casual view
the place seemed very much like
a French garrison town in time of
peace. In the afternoon of the
day of our arrival, we went by
automobiles to see the front lines.
As we drove along the fine French
roads, through a fairly level country, we passed many lories moving
forward or to the rear; here and
there we saw a camp of horses, or
a park of supply wagons; occasionally a group of soldiers would
saunter by, usually carrying picks
or spades, rifles being conspicuously absent. Now and then an
automobile carrying officers, or a
man on motorcycle, would dash
by at a break-neck pace; but the
country seemed peaceful.
The first indication of our approach to the front lines, was
sight of a row of captive observation balloons; they were placed
about three miles behind the front
and three or four miles apart;
and thus, from a distance, marked
the position of the lines. Sometimes six or eight were visible at
once. As we approached, the distant booming of cannon could be
heard; but this section was inactive at the time of our visit, and
the firing was not rapid. We left
the automobiles and went to an
observation post, which was placed
at the edge of a wood, so concealed by blanches as to be invisible at a small distance. From
this point we could look over the
lines a short mile ahead. It was
an interesting and surprising
sight: a broad, very gently rolling
country, with patches of wood
here and there, with the grass gone
from the part near the trenches,
which, in this region, were not
'very easily distinguished. Behind
us was the row of French captive
balloons, and at a greater distance
in front the enemy balloons; here
and there overhead an aeroplane
floated in the sky, the noise of its
engine distinctly audible; frequently we would hear the sound
of a bursting shell and see the

Extracts From "Hank" Chalmer's Letters.
"Hank" is now with the Y. M. C. A.
serving at the front. He will ever be
remembered as a Hopkins all-around
man, and for his genial disposition.
The following are extracts from his
letters:

"If things work out as I expect,
I shall be assigned to a dugout
on tire French front working with
the French soldiers. There has
been a call for volunteers for these
posts, because they can't send a
man there against his will; so, I
volunteered, and they think I shall
be accepted. If I get the job it
will put me on the fighting line
with the most marvelous opportunity for service I have had.
The French people are wonderful,
and I hope I may be able to help
them in their courageous fight.
They say that we can render no
more important service than our
work among the French."
"I am now only about twenty
miles from the front, and there is
so much snow that it is impossible
to proceed at once to my Foyer.
It is hard to get to, anyway, and,
especially so, with two feet of
snow on the ground. I shall stay
where I am today and go on again
tomorrow. Last night I slept in
a room having one pane of glass,
the other openings were covered
with thin gauze. The mirror in
the room had a hole in the side
and there was a hole in the wall.
The shutters and ceiling were
scarred with holes. All this
wreckage was done by bombs."
*
*
"I am in the midst of things. I
got up at five o'clock to take a
train for my post. It was pitch
dark and there were no lights.
All the cars in the little narrowguage railway were filled, but the
conductor gave Bill and myself
a place in an empty mail car. It
was cold and we had to keep moving to keep warm * * * * We
had to stop at headquarters for
a safe-conduct pass and missed the,
train, so at nine o'clock tonight
I shall take the train to the last
train stop, arriving about eleven
o'clock and must walk the rest of
the way, about six kilometers.
* * * Arrived at eleven
o'clock, and the men found a place
for Bill and me to sleep in a barn.
We slept on the floor without
blankets. It was cold, but endurable. * * * * I arrived all
right where I now am, and

"I was awakened about three
o'clock last night with the sound
of firing. The Foyer was shaking, and I could see the flash of
the guns lighting up the sky.
They were going so fast that I
could hardly distinguish separate
shots and the noise was deafening. It lasted about an hour and
then quieted down. They expect
two or three bombardments. * *
* * The French clearly have the
upper hand. Defensively they cannot be beaten, and it is only a
matter of time before Germany
is licked. The troops are splendid
and are wonderful fighters."
"Yesterday was the first open
day for my Foyer. The building
was full of soldiers most of the
day. They are tremendously appreciative of the Foyer."
"Yesterday there was a presentation of the legion of honor to a
captain, and the military medal
to a corporal of the Zouaves. First
they had a Review, a salute to the
colors, then presentation, and another Review and salute. The
Review passed right by where I
stood, and every officer saluted
me. When the colors passed, I,
of course, stood at attention and
saluted, and the color bearer, who
is a lieutenant, dipped the regimental colors of one of the finest
fighting units in the world in
recognition. Of course they did
all this to me because I am an
American."
"I said I was going to mention
barrages and the like only as I
would mention rain, but as I have
mentioned rain once, I'll take another shot at the guns. It is especially interesting tonight because they are going on the complete swing of three quarters of a
circle. I can hear the guns in
all four directions, front, back
and both sides. One quarter,
however, is open. The way the
guns go, though, you feel as if
you were completely surrounded.
The 'noble six hundred' haven't
anything on me. I can add one
direction to their three."

Lauds Freshman Spirit.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER: t

Sir—As the college year is
drawing to a close, I take this opportunity to say a few words
about niy class and to the University.
I have heard some fellows complaining of the lack of spirit in
the Freshman class. It seems to
me that when we got organized,
after the first few weeks, we have
had a splendid spirit. Certainly
the various athletic teams cannot
kick about the Freshmen not being well represented on them. To
the football squad, we gave Carey
and Jones, and many others,
whose spirit was none the less
good, even if their opportunities
were less great. Baseball stars
from the class of '21 were Weillye; Webb and J. Jones. Track
had Mulliken and Van Ness. On
the lacrosse team were Brennan
and Sadtler. Besides the men
named, there were many others
who came out and gave of their
best, that Hopkins might be successful in the field of sports. Our
class, as well as the University,
is deeply grateful to them.
In other things, too, the Freshmen have maintained a fine spirit.
The few,regulations set down for
them, during the first term were
very well adhered to. Altogether,
the class promises to be Ole to
maintain, with honor to itself, the
traditions of the University.
I look back •upon the college
year, now ending, as one of the
happiest of my life, and as I look
forward to next year, I feel considerably saddened, when I think
of the s changes that will have
taken place, of the students who
will not return, and, perhaps, I
myself will not be here. If this
last should be the case, I want to
thank the professors for their fairness to me in my studies, and to
ask the students to join me in a
good, old Hullabaloo for Hopkins.
FRESHMAN.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—We have at the University

The Physics II Lab.
(An Extract from the Will of those
students finishing Physics II.)
* * * And the little Place
Up under the Roof of the M. E. Building
We leave to the class that takes Physics II
Next Year.
You will go in, in the afternoon (perhaps),
Find out from the Instructor what its
all about,
And get some Data.
If you think there is too much work
attached
Accidentally smash a vital part of the
apparatus
Before too many readings are made.
You will pursue the elusive Milligram
With the Meter Stick.
You will read to a tenth of a division,
And repeat it, getting a reading ten
divisions out.
When the seconds-clock stops at a crucial point
You will have to tickle it with a hatchet.
You will crack ice like Bartenders,
And concoct strange mixtures
Of mercury, sodium, sulphate, camphor
And universal, wax.
You will take as your watchword
The term "Arbitration";
That is, if readings do not agree,
Reconcile them.
After a time you will become so good
That you will be able to report on experiments
Without performing them.
This will be lucky, as just before
Tne end of the term
You will' be informed that you cannot
Take the examination until you report
On about a dozen experiments
That you will have never thought of
doing.

smoke and earth thrown up where
it had struck; once a fire burst
out where a dump of fusees had
been struck; but there was a general suggestion of peacefulness
over the country, and, strain our
eyes as we might, not a soldier
was visible; we looked through
the powerful glasses at the observation post—not a man to be
seen; the place seemed deserted.
But well we knew that thousands
of men were in the trenches or in
the dugouts within a short distance of us, paying the price of
eternal vigilance that liberty
might be saved. Death, from an
invisible source, hovered about;
and the officers warned us that
if we exposed ourselves to view
a German shell was likely soon to
land among us. This lesson was
taught us in a very decisive way
a few days later at Fort Douaumont near Verdun. After seeing
the various underground passages,
• we had gone on top to look about.
As near Chalons the country
looked peaceful and deserted. A
French 75, so camouflaged that it
was hardly visible at a distance
of 50 yards, barked sharply from
time to time, as tho' to indicate
that the fortress was not open to
strangers. We stayed but a few
minutes, and had scarcely gotten
under shelter, when, with a loud
explosion, a German 77 landed
where we had been sitting, followed ten or fifteen seconds later
by a second. It was probably
sport to the German gunners, but
they didn't see us again.
It was absorbing to watch the
reconnoitering aeroplanes. They
swept majestically through the
air like great soaring buzzards.
As we looked, a black splotch
would suddenly appear in the air
in the neighborhood of a plane;
then another, and another, until
eight or ten could be seem. They
marked the bursting of the antiaircraft shells. Gradually they
dissolved and disappeared, and the
aeroplane sailed on undisturbed,
seemingly contemptuous of the efforts to bring it down.
As a
fact, very few are destroyed in
this way.
The battle field about Douaumont was one vast collection of
shell holes; from a distance the
hill looks as though it had been
trampled over by great herds; but
a nearer view shows that the soil
has all been overturned and the
formerly smooth surface is now
merely a collection of intersecting
shell holes. Not a foot of the
original surface remains. The
French alone fired 360,000 shells
in one day when they retook the
fortress. It was gruesome sight;
cartridges, broken guns,fragments
of shells old accoutrements, lay
scattered
'about. Some shell holes
contained rain water stained a
deep red. An arm, a foot, or
larger parts of bodies could be

seen in places projecting from the
sides of the holes; and there was
a stench that pervaded the whole
place. There must be thousands
of bodies covered up in the ground
on this hill. In the immediate
neighborhood of Fort Douaumont,
though they had been clearing up
for several months, remains were
still being uncovered. We found
the same general conditions at
Vimy Ridge; the ground was so
torn by shells, that the former
German trenches were scarcely
recognizable.
In our drives across the country, we passed many villages in
utter ruin. Some had been destroyed in the natural course of
battles, others in sheer wantonness. The Kaiser is lately reported to have congratulated the
people of Aix-la-Chapelle that
their country had not suffered the
fate of northern France. But
what can be said of a government
that, for its own advantage, is
willing to inflict such disaster on
a neighbor and be complaisant because they have been spared? We
want no German peace. It is to
be hoped that the Allies may obtain so complete. a victory that
they will be able to hold the German government strictly responsible for all it has done. In the
words of Premier Lloyd George,
"Swash-buckling through the
streets of Europe must be treated
as a crime."
